node.title: Viscoelasticity model in RACCOON
node.bodyText:
Hi, I didn't see any related discussions on this board so I'm posting a new one on this topic.
I'm trying to implement a viscoelastic material into RACCOON for fracture simulation. The only related documentation for RACCOON that allows for viscoelasticity without plasticity that I saw is ComputeLargeDeformationStress which takes in an elasticity and viscoelasticity model.
However, some other aspects of the RACCOON + viscoelastic marriage weren't clear. For example, ComputeLargeDeformationStress requires finite deformation measures, and those viscoelastic models that use finite strain measures require cree updates, and it's not clear how to include creep updates in the RACCOON framework. I'm wondering if anyone's seen some documentation anywhere that goes into this in a bit more detailed manner.
Here's my input file, though there's an ADerror as it stands now:
*** ERROR ***
...:173.3:
The following error occurred in the MaterialBase 'stress' of type ComputeLargeDeformationStress.

The declared AD material property 'stress' of type 'RankTwoTensorTempl<double>'
is already retrieved or declared as a non-AD property of type 'RankTwoTensorTempl<double>'.

`E = 660e6
nu = 0.3
K = '${fparse E/3/(1-2*nu)}'
G = '${fparse E/2/(1+nu)}'

Gc = 2.7 #need good values for this
l = 0.02

output_name = 'tendon_fracture_predamaged_visco'

[MultiApps]
  [fracture]
    type = TransientMultiApp
    input_files = fracture_predamaged.i
    cli_args = 'Gc=${Gc};l=${l}'
    execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END'
  []
[]

[Transfers]
  [from_d]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    from_multi_app = 'fracture'
    variable = d
    source_variable = d
  []
  [to_psie]
    type = MultiAppCopyTransfer
    to_multi_app = 'fracture'
    variable = psie
    source_variable = psie
  []
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  #density = 1e4
[]

[Mesh]
  [generated]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 40
    ny = 20
    xmax = 2
    ymax = 1
  []
  construct_side_list_from_node_list = true
  #uniform_refine = 1
[]

[Adaptivity]
  marker = marker
  initial_marker = marker
  initial_steps = 1
  stop_time = 0
  max_h_level = 1
  [Markers]
    [marker]
      type = BoxMarker
      bottom_left = '0.7 0 0'
      top_right = '1.3 1 0'
      outside = DO_NOTHING
      inside = REFINE
    []
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [disp_x]
  []
  [disp_y]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [fx]
  []
  [d]
  []
[]

[ICs]
  [IC_damage]
    type = RndBoundingBoxIC
    x1 = 0.95
    x2 = 1.05
    y1 = 0.3
    y2 = 0.7
    mx_invalue = 1.0
    mn_invalue = 0.9
    mx_outvalue = 0
    mn_outvalue = 0
    variable = d
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [SolidMechanics]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    use_displaced_mesh = true
    use_automatic_differentiation = true 
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [left_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = left
    value = 0
  []
  [left_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = left
    value = 0
  []
  [right_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = right
    value = 0
  []
  [right_x]
    type = FunctionNeumannBC
    function = '5e5 * 0.1 * (1 + sin(2*pi*t*5))'
    #type = FunctionDirichletBC
    #function = '0.001 * (sin(2*pi*t*5))'
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = right
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [bulk]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'K G'
    prop_values = '${K} ${G}'
  []
  [degradation]
    type = PowerDegradationFunction
    property_name = g
    expression = (1-d)^p*(1-eta)+eta
    phase_field = d
    parameter_names = 'p eta'
    parameter_values = '2 1e-6'
  []
  [./strain]
    type = ADComputeFiniteStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  [../]
  [defgrad]
    type = ComputeDeformationGradient
  []
  [elasticity]
    type = HenckyIsotropicElasticity
    bulk_modulus = K
    shear_modulus = G
    phase_field = d
    degradation_function = g
    output_properties = 'elastic_strain psie'
    outputs = exodus
  []
  [viscoelasticity]
    type = GeneralizedKelvinVoigtModel
    creep_modulus = '10e9 10e9'
    creep_viscosity = '1 10'
    poisson_ratio = 0.3
    young_modulus = 660e6
  [../]
  [stress]
    type = ComputeLargeDeformationStress
    elasticity_model = elasticity
    viscoelasticity_model = viscoelasticity
    output_properties = 'stress'
    outputs = exodus
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [./update]
    type = LinearViscoelasticityManager
    viscoelastic_model = viscoelasticity
    use_automatic_differentiation = true
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [Fx]
    type = NodalSum
    variable = fx
    boundary = right
  []
  [damage_max]
    type = ElementExtremeValue
    value_type = max
    variable = d
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  end_time = 1
  dt = 0.01
[]

[Outputs]
  file_base = '${output_name}'
  exodus = true
  csv = true
  print_linear_residuals = false
[]

Hello
For the current error, ComputeLargeDeformationStress seems to expect stress to be an AD tensor property.
But the producer of stress, whichever it is, is producing it as a regular tensor property
You will need to use
[Debug]
  show_material_props = true

to sort out who is producing what and with what type.

Got it. Looks like it was either the GeneralizedKelvinVoigtModel or the LinearViscoelasticityManager. Commenting out either of those two fixes the error, but thne there needs to be another way to include viscous effects.

node.title: Negative Jacobians During Thermal Expansion and Elastic Deformation
node.bodyText:
Hey all,
I'm running a pretty large mesh (generated via the Reactor module in MOOSE) doing a thermal solve w/ HeatConduction and deformation with IsotropicElasticityTensor, ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain, ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress, and Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic. I'll provide an example of my use of each below.
The problem I'm running in to, is negative Jacobians specifically at certain TRI mesh blocks. The blocks where this happens are the TRIs in created from PolygonConcentricCircleMeshGenerator, almost all occurring in bottom of the geometry (where the reflector is defined). I've seen this happen before where a mesh element is small and the expansion inverts the mesh, but that's not what's happening here. All the volumes in the error report are positive, nothing stands out when I visually inspect the mesh, I even increased the size of the TRI elements and still get the errors.
Here's the geometry and the specific blocks that get the errors:


Any ideas on what's causing this? Feel free to ask questions, I'm a bit in the dark of how to approach debugging this, so any help is very appreciated.
Edit: Also of note, my first attempt to debug this was setting the thermal expansion coefficient for the entire reflector material to 0. This worked for a handful of non-linear iterations, but eventually failed.
I'll attach my input and the error output so you can check it out. Apologies in advance for how large the input it, I generate it via a few scripts so it's not very human-readable.
input.txt
problems.txt
Thanks y'all.

Hello
I can see some really narrow tris in the problem.e mesh. Did you try to coarsen the mesh?
The mesh diagnostics generator detects thousands of non-planar sides.
*** Info ***
Number of non-planar element sides detected: 19388

Are these the ones on the outer part of cylinders? I think we expect those to be non planar on a second order mesh. That should be ok if so. We should still check that:
n_azim * n_pins * n_axial is equal to 19388
does this run with first order?
Guillaume

Apologies, I uploaded incorrectly. Problem.txt is the exodus mesh of the problem subdomains reported from the error output, as you probably figured out. I ran a 2nd order run (slightly different geometry, same errors) and I'll attach the actual error output and the mesh generator file so you can check it out and rebuild the mesh yourself.
core_gen.txt
error.txt
I'll check this number of sides.
I just ran a case with 1st order and it worked with no errors! Does that mean it's a 2nd order problem? Something to do with stress tensor calculations on the 2nd order tri elements?
I regenerated a new mesh using the quad_center_elements = false for all PolygonConcentricCircleMeshGenerator, so it may get further. I don't see any way to avoid TRI elements in HexagonConcentricCircleAdaptiveBoundaryMeshGenerator so it may still break.

did you try with PRISM18?
To get those you have to extrude from a lower order TRI. So TRI6 instead of TRI7
see tri_element_type in
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/PolygonConcentricCircleMeshGenerator.html
EDIT I tried and the PeripheralRingMeshGenerator does not support higher order for now. i ll hit up the reactor module team
EDIT how did you even get PRISM21? I see PRISM18 from the conversion?

There is two groups of problematic elements in error.txt.
(hmin = small side, hmax = largest side)
Some are 0.2 for hmin and 10 for hmax
and some are 0.03 for hmin and 10 for hmax
Both groups have a single side with 1 nullptr element? Do you know why that is? Are they on an actual external boundary of the mesh?
both are very thin. If we could have a less fine discretization (with less sectors) I think it could help
quad_center_elements = false  actually does not help make nice tri elements. With a quad element at the center, the mesh looks better imo
EDIT I tried and the PeripheralRingMeshGenerator does not support higher order for now. i ll hit up the reactor module team

Something to do with stress tensor calculations on the 2nd order tri elements?

that's possible. Or something to do with prism21 being finicky.
Note that you don't use all 21 nodes, in the error.txt output 3 nodes have no dofs

Could you please share a version of the thermo-mechanics input that works with the mesh from core_gen.txt out of the box?
I am getting missing subdomains, I am guessing you used a different mesh for the input.i(txt) file

node.title: Mesh object for creating internal surface?
node.bodyText:
Hi, I'm trying to create an internal surface in a rectangular mesh to use an interface BC with. This is the setup:

(NB, the surface does not cut through the blue box). Previously, with the case where theta = 0, I had simply created two different blocks in the lower (black) rectangle with BoundingBoxNodeSetGenerator (even though both sides had the same material properties), and then I used SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator to define the surface.
Now that I have an angle, is it still possible to do this, or would I need to try to do it directly from the mesh generation software? I was having issues with that in the past (refining specific subregions within the meshing software and still retaining domain names) hence why I did the subdomain definitions within MOOSE.

Hello
Can you use the ParsedGenerateSideset?
this can work with an equation, if the nodes exist already at the right location
Guillaume

this should work, thanks. Is there a way to run an input file and have it output the mesh (without running the whole simulation) with the moose-defined sidesets viewable in paraview? Just to be sure that my equation is defining it appropriately.
add --mesh-only on the command line after the input file name

thanks. but I just realized that actually, this might not work- I'm defining a variable jump so I need to be able to define different variables on each side of the sideset. Would there be a way to split the block into two based on the defined sideset?
if the expression you use to define the sideset is good enough for ParsedGenerateSideset, then it will work very similarly in ParsedSubdomainGenerator which you can use to split the mesh into blocks
hmm okay this should work, thank you!

node.title: The following material properties are declared on block 18 by multiple materials
node.bodyText:
I am working on Multiphase field modeling incorporating the elasticity-plasticity model. This is the code I am using:
[./Stiffness_martix1]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorConstantRotationCP
    C_ijkl = '72300 59400 35800 72300 35800 88400 22000 22000 24000'
    base_name = matrix1
    fill_method = symmetric9
  [../]


  [./stress_matrix1]
    type = ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityRotation
    crystal_plasticity_models = 'trial_xtalpl1'
    tan_mod_type = exact
    base_name = matrix1
  [../]

[./trial_xtalpl1]
    type = CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate
    number_slip_systems = 32
    slip_sys_file_name = slip_sys_tin.txt
    base_name = matrix1
    ao = 2.5e-4
    gss_a = 2
    r = 1.4
    h = 60.3
    gss_initial = 23
 [../]

 [./strain_1]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = matrix1
    eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain1
  [../]

  [./Stiffness_matrix2]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorConstantRotationCP
    C_ijkl = '72300 59400 35800 72300 35800 88400 22000 22000 24000'
    base_name = matrix2
    fill_method = symmetric9
    euler_angle_1 = 0
    euler_angle_2 = 45
    euler_angle_3 = 90
  [../]

  [./stress_matrix2]
    type = ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityRotation
    crystal_plasticity_models = 'trial_xtalpl2'
    tan_mod_type = exact
    base_name = matrix2
  [../]

  [./trial_xtalpl2]
    type = CrystalPlasticityKalidindiUpdate
    number_slip_systems = 32
    slip_sys_file_name = slip_sys_tin.txt
    base_name = matrix2
    ao = 2.5e-4
    gss_a = 2
    r = 1.4
    h = 60.3
    gss_initial = 23
 [../]

  [./strain_2]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = matrix2
    eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain1
  [../]

  [./Stiffness_ppt]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    youngs_modulus = 97000
    base_name = ppt
  [../]

  [./stress_ppt]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    base_name = ppt
  [../]

  [./strain_3]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
    base_name = ppt
    eigenstrain_names = eigenstrain1
  [../]

  [./volumExp_strainmatrix1]
    type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    temperature = eta_ppt
    thermal_expansion_coeff = 0.1
    stress_free_temperature = 0.0
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain1
    base_name = matrix1
  [../]

  [./volumExp_strainmatrix2]
    type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    temperature = eta_ppt
    thermal_expansion_coeff = 0.1
    stress_free_temperature = 0.0
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain1
    base_name = matrix2
  [../]

  [./volumExp_strainppt]
    type = ComputeThermalExpansionEigenstrain
    temperature = eta_ppt
    thermal_expansion_coeff = 0.1
    stress_free_temperature = 0.0
    eigenstrain_name = eigenstrain1
    base_name = ppt
  [../]

  [./global_stress]
    type = MultiPhaseStressMaterial
    phase_base = 'matrix1  matrix2  ppt'
    h =       'h1   h2   h3'
  [../]
[]

[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
      [./generalized_plane_strain]
        strain = Finite
        displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
        add_variables = true
        incremental = true
        temperature = eta_ppt
        generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_xy stress_xz stress_yx stress_yy stress_yz stress_zx stress_zy stress_zz strain_xx strain_xy strain_xz  strain_yx  strain_yy strain_yz strain_zx strain_zy strain_zz  vonmises_stress'  
     [../]
[]`

I worked with 2phase- matrix1, ppt. The code worked fine. Now that I am adding another phase matrix2, I am getting this error:
`The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".

The following material properties are declared on block 18 by multiple materials:
  Material Property             Material Objects
  Euler_angles                  Stiffness_ppt Stiffness_matrix1 Stiffness_matrix2 generalized_plane_strain_strain global_stress strain_1 strain_2 strain_3 strain_xx_generalized_plane_strain strain_xy_generalized_plane_strain strain_xz_generalized_plane_strain strain_yx_generalized_plane_strain strain_yy_generalized_plane_strain strain_yz_generalized_plane_strain strain_zx_generalized_plane_strain strain_zy_generalized_plane_strain strain_zz_generalized_plane_strain stress_ppt stress_matrix2 stress_xx_generalized_plane_strain stress_xy_generalized_plane_strain stress_xz_generalized_plane_strain stress_yx_generalized_plane_strain stress_yy_generalized_plane_strain stress_yz_generalized_plane_strain stress_zx_generalized_plane_strain stress_zy_generalized_plane_strain stress_zz_generalized_plane_strain trial_xtalpl1 trial_xtalpl2  volumExp_strainppt volumExp_strainmatrix1 volumExp_strainmatrix2 vonmises_stress_generalized_plane_strain `


What change should I make to fix that error?

Hello
I think Euler_angles did not get properly pre-fixed with the base_name in the materials that defined it.
Should it be? Euler angles are different for each phase?
Guillaume

I defined Euler angle - (0,0,0) for phase 1, and (0,45,90) for phase 2 in the code.
 [./Stiffness_martix1]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorConstantRotationCP
    C_ijkl = '72300 59400 35800 72300 35800 88400 22000 22000 24000'
    base_name = matrix1
    fill_method = symmetric9
    euler_angle_1 = 0
    euler_angle_2 = 0
    euler_angle_3 = 0
  [../]

[./Stiffness_matrix2]
    type = ComputeElasticityTensorConstantRotationCP
    C_ijkl = '72300 59400 35800 72300 35800 88400 22000 22000 24000'
    base_name = matrix2
    fill_method = symmetric9
    euler_angle_1 = 0
    euler_angle_2 = 45
    euler_angle_3 = 90
  [../]

But getting the error message. How can I pre-fix the Euler angles with the base_name in the materials that you mentioned in your comment?
you'll have change the code to add the base_name prefix to the name in declareProperty....(base_name + "euler_angles")

node.title: temperature out of range in Water97FluidProperties
node.bodyText:
I want to do a thermal hydraulics problem which is in follwing:

in the THM part, there is input file.
inlet_T = 308.15 # K
m_dot_in = 12.13 # kg/s
press = '${fparse 101325 + 1e3 * 9.8 * 7.4}' # Pa

# pipe
A_pipe = '${fparse 2 * 0.0215^2 * 1.7312 - pi * 0.0181^2}'
D_h = '${fparse 4 * A_pipe / (pi * 0.0352)}'
length = 0.39 #m

[GlobalParams]
  initial_p = ${press}
  initial_vel = 0.204#m/s
  initial_T = ${inlet_T}
  gravity_vector = '0 0 0'

  rdg_slope_reconstruction = full
  closures = thm_closures
  fp = water
[]

[Closures]
  [thm_closures]
    type = Closures1PhaseNone
  []
[]

[FluidProperties]
  [water]
    type = Water97FluidProperties
  []
[]


[AuxVariables]
  [T_wall]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []
  [T]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [Tw_aux]
    type = ADMaterialRealAux
    block = pipe
    variable = T_wall
    property = T_wall
  []
[]

[Materials]
  # wall friction closure
  [f_mat]
    type = ADWallFrictionChurchillMaterial
    block = pipe
    D_h = D_h
    f_D = f_D
    vel = vel
    rho = rho
    mu = mu
  []
  
  # Re = \rho * vel * D_h / mu
  [Re_mat]
    type = ADReynoldsNumberMaterial
    Re = Re 
    rho = rho 
    D_h = D_h
    mu = mu
    vel = vel
    block = pipe
  []
  # Pr = C_p  * mu / k 
  [Pr_mat]
    type = ADPrandtlNumberMaterial
    Pr = Pr 
    cp = cp
    mu = mu
    k = k
    block = pipe
  []
  [Nu_mat]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    block = pipe
    # Dittus-Boelter
    expression = '0.021 * pow(Re, 0.8) * pow(Pr, 0.4)'
    property_name = 'Nu'
    material_property_names = 'Re Pr'
  []
  [Hw_mat]
    type = ADConvectiveHeatTransferCoefficientMaterial
    D_h = D_h
    k = k
    Nu = Nu
    Hw = Hw
    block = pipe
  []
  [T_wall]
    type = ADTemperatureWall3EqnMaterial
    Hw = Hw
    T = T
    q_wall = q_wall
  []
[]


[Components]
  [inlet]
    type = InletMassFlowRateTemperature1Phase
    input = 'pipe:in'
    m_dot = ${m_dot_in}
    T = ${inlet_T}
  []
  [pipe]
    type = FlowChannel1Phase
    position = '0 0 0'
    orientation = '0 0 1'
    length = ${length}
    n_elems = 39 
    A = ${A_pipe} 
    D_h = ${D_h} 
  []
  [hxconn]
    type = HeatTransferFromExternalAppHeatFlux1Phase
    flow_channel = pipe
    P_hf = ${fparse pi * 0.0181 * 2}
  []
  [outlet]
    type = Outlet1Phase
    input = 'pipe:out'
    p = ${press}
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [pc]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  line_search = basic

  start_time = 0
  end_time = 31536000

  steady_state_detection = true
  steady_state_tolerance = 1e-8

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'

  nl_rel_tol = 1e-8
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-8
  nl_max_its = 25
  [TimeStepper]
    type = FunctionDT
    function = dts
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [dts]  
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0 60 3600 86400 31536000'
    y = '10 10 360 86400 86400'
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true

  [console]
    type = Console
    max_rows = 1
    outlier_variable_norms = false
  []
  print_linear_residuals = false
[]
the wrong is
libMesh terminating:
Temperature -376998 is out of range in water: inRegion()
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1

and I try to use gdb follow code, I find the temperature is right in RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureVelocityIC, why temperature wrong in Water97FluidProperties? Thanks for you help.

Hello
Do you have a backtrace from gdb? This would help us look at the routines in Water97FP
Guillaume

Sure, I am not very understand the GDB, so i write the steps which I have done clearly.
I reed the debug part in MOOSE web,
b MPI_Abort
bt
and part of output is
 0x00007fffef624092 in Water97FluidProperties::inRegion (this=0x555555d0def0, pressure=173845, temperature=-376997.58328186366)
    at /home/wang/projects/moose/modules/fluid_properties/src/fluidproperties/Water97FluidProperties.C:1157
#6  0x00007fffef680d22 in Water97FluidProperties::rho_from_p_T_template<MetaPhysicL::DualNumber<double, MetaPhysicL::NumberArray<2ul, double>, false> > (this=0x555555d0def0, pressure=..., temperature=...)

    at /home/wang/projects/moose/modules/fluid_properties/build/header_symlinks/Water97FluidProperties.h:2003
#15 0x00007ffff105de05 in RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureFunctionVelocityIC::value (this=0x555555f28320, p=...)
    at /home/wang/projects/moose/modules/thermal_hydraulics/src/ics/RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureFunctionVelocityIC.C:46
so I set breakpoints in RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureFunctionVelocityI and Water97FluidProperties
Thread 1 "pulse-dbg" hit Breakpoint 3, RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureFunctionVelocityIC::value (this=0x555555f28320, p=...)
    at /home/wang/projects/moose/modules/thermal_hydraulics/src/ics/RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureFunctionVelocityIC.C:46
46        const Real e = _fp.e_from_p_rho(_p[_qp], rho);
(gdb) info locals
vel = 0.20399999999999999
rho = 994.07047349434276
e = 6.9533462538108351e-310
(gdb) print _T[_qp]
$1 = (const double &) @0x5555562eda50: 308.14999999999992
(gdb) n
Currently Executing
  Performing Initial Setup
    Projecting Initial Solutions
Thread 1 "pulse-dbg" hit Breakpoint 4, Water97FluidProperties::inRegion (this=0x555555d0def0, pressure=173845, temperature=-376997.58328186366)
    at /home/wang/projects/moose/modules/fluid_properties/src/fluidproperties/Water97FluidProperties.C:1157
1157        mooseException("Temperature ", temperature, " is out of range in ", name(), ": inRegion()");
(gdb) info locals
region = 32767
(gdb) print temperature
$2 = -376997.58328186366
(gdb) 
I don't konw the Water97 how to get the temperature, because I not find such as coupledVariable function in Water97FluidProperties.C.

Hello
You'll want to set a breakpoint on RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureFunctionVelocityIC.C:46 and see which location is problematic. Clearly the one you first stopped on was  not, T was 308.
But later at another qp, likely in another element, T is -376997.58328186366

Yes, you said is what i did, there is my breakpoint info
1       breakpoint     keep y   0x00007ffff105de0e in RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureFunctionVelocityIC::value(libMesh::Point const&) 
                                                   at /home/wang/projects/moose/modules/thermal_hydraulics/src/ics/RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureFunctionVelocityIC.C:47
2       breakpoint     keep y   0x00007fffef624029 in Water97FluidProperties::inRegion(double, double) const 
                                                   at /home/wang/projects/moose/modules/fluid_properties/src/fluidproperties/Water97FluidProperties.C:1157

so how to find where the temperature going bad?

ok so in the code for that IC object you can see that the temperature is retrieved as a coupledValue, which means it's computed in that object.
putting breakpoints in RhoEAFromPressureTemperatureFunctionVelocityIC wont tell us much.
I think we need to find the auxkernel which computes temperature.
Regardless, this is an initialization issue. If you fix the intial conditions everywhere, the problem will go away

I think we need to find the auxkernel which computes temperature.
is the TemperatureAux? in /home/wang/projects/moose/modules/fluid_properties/src/auxkernels/TemperatureAux.C?
is there a TemperatureAux in your simulation?

t seems that all member functions can call the parameter temperature

While it is computed by the FluidProperty, likely from a T_from_v_e routine, I think it's best to first track in your simulation what is setting the temperature and how

no, I only set
inlet_T = 308.15 # K
initial_T = ${inlet_T}

If I set the initial_condition of T, there is wrong
*** ERROR ***
The initial condition 'T_moose' is being defined on a block that already has an initial condition defined.

I know what's you mean, but I don't konw how to track the variable temperature

you can step in NewtonSolve in NewtonInversion to see how the newton solve is doing.
This is a 1D newton solve so it should be very simple.
I dont imagine something is wrong there though.

p rho _T_intial_guess tolerance, all is right.

what are p and rho ? If you compute rho(p, T=-30000) do you get close to the rho there?

node.title: How can a RealVectorValue be passed to cleavage_plane_normal in the ACInterfaceCleavageFracture
node.bodyText:
Dear all moose users,
How can a RealVectorValue be passed to cleavage_plane_normal in the ACInterfaceCleavageFracture?
I am calculating the cleavage_plane_normal in a material properties as RealVectorValue, which is the stress_direction
then constructed  this in [AuxKernels] as a AuxVariables
[./direction_1]
    type = MaterialRealVectorValueAux
    property = stress_direction
    variable = direction_1
    component = 0
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  [../]
  [./direction_2]
    type = MaterialRealVectorValueAux
    property = stress_direction
    variable = direction_2
    component = 1
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  [../]
  [./direction_3]
    type = MaterialRealVectorValueAux
    property = stress_direction
    variable = direction_3
    component = 2
    execute_on = TIMESTEP_END
  [../]
  [./build_vector]
    type = BuildArrayVariableAux
    variable = vector
    component_variables = 'direction_1 direction_2 direction_3'
  [../]

but  I got error in the step of passing the value into cleavage_plane_normal
" connot convert filed 'Kernels/ACInterfaceCleavageFracture/cleavage_plane_normal' value vector to float"
[./ACInterfaceCleavageFracture]
    type = ACInterfaceCleavageFracture
    variable = c
    beta_penalty = 1
    cleavage_plane_normal = vector
 [../]

How can I make this come true?
Best regards,
Lifeng

Hello
It expects a single constant value:
  params.addRequiredParam<RealVectorValue>("cleavage_plane_normal",
                                           "Normal to the weak cleavage plane");

it does not expect a vector variable.
If you want to use a vector variable, likely because you want a spatial dependence, you will need to create a copy of this kernel, with a different name, and change the code a little bit to use:
params.addCoupledVar("cleavage_plane_normal", "description");

for the parameter
and then use the vector routines from the Coupleable API
Guillaume

hello,
What if i just want it simple?
it expects in form of  cleavage_plane_normal = '0.707 0.707 0'
but I cannot make it with cleavage_plane_normal  = 'direction_1 direction_2 direction_3'
where the direction_i is output from MaterialRealVectorValueAux using component = i
Lifeng

no you cant do that without changing the code.
Replacing the constant vector with a material property is the same amount of effort as using a field variable

Thanks for the answer
it works by changing the code ACInterfaceCleavageFracture with
_cleavage_plane_normal(getMaterialPropertyByName<RealVectorValue>("cleavage_plane_normal"))
Lifeng

evidence 1:
Try AbaqusUserElement  UO  with external uel.f

Conclusion:
I do not know it's expected result of the abaqus user-element implementation in moose or not. However, it seems like each processor called the plugin uel.f across all 27 elements, but we clearly see the correct parallel partition with 4 cpus.
Question 1:
From the above background about AbaqusUserElement, If I deleted the DynamicLibraryLoader function especially for uel.f Plugin, I wanna directly output the jelem=elem->id()+1 within UELThread.C w/o plugin function _uel():

                  std::cout << "Element number is           " << jelem << "\n";


the new wrong Output is not the same as the above old Output with plugin uel.f, I cannot understand this difference, how can I get the same Output without plugin ?
new wrong Output:

                            Time Step 0, time = 0

                            Time Step 1, time = 10, dt = 10

                            Element number is:           13
                            Element number is:           14
                            Element number is:           15

                            Element number is:            2
                            Element number is:            3
                            Element number is:           10


The new wrong Output only for one processor and also executed on EXEC_PRE_KERNELS.



evidence 2:
Try sub- UO class based on parent class ElementUserObject
[which only output current element ID with _current_elem->id()+1],
the output on terminal as shown in below:

mesh information [same]:

                           Parallelism:
                                    Num Processors:            4
                                    Num Threads:               1
                           Mesh:
                                    Parallel Type:             replicated
                                    Mesh Dimension:            3
                                    Spatial Dimension:         3
                           Nodes:
                                    Total:                     64
                                    Local:                     30
                                    Min/Max/Avg:               6/30/16
                           Elems:
                                    Total:                     27
                                    Local:                     8
                                    Min/Max/Avg:               6/8/6
                                    Num Subdomains:            1
                                    Num Partitions:            4
                                    Partitioner:               metis



Output [1. the execute_on EXEC_PRE_KERNELS]:

                            Time Step 0, time = 0

                            Time Step 1, time = 10, dt = 10
                            Element number is:           10



Conclusion:
this output is totally incorrect. From my view, I just wanna output the individual ElementID of each element. This is to say, the threadJoin( ) and finalize( ) are not necessary for this expectation. In AbaqusUserElement UO, it did not use the the threadJoin( ) and finalize( ) as well.



Question:
From the two evidence 1, 2, The only AbaqusUserElement can output ElementID of all elements but duplicated.
Although this ElementID example is simple, it's important to implement elemental value individually. Is there any way to focus on only each element ? by the way, I understood the UOs BlockAverageValue and HomogenizationConstraints, which calculated Elemental value from quadrature points loop, threadJoining into shared map container, and gatherSum to global value. However, it is different from the expectation of this discussion, I just wanna perform the quadrature points loop, calculate each Elemental value, and output it element by element. This idea maybe the same as Elemental value postprocessor for Paraview visualization.
the descent trend :
domain (FEProblem) (global)   --->  subProblems (processors)  --->  subDomains (blocks) (each processor)
Elements (block) (each processor)  --->  quadrature points (Element) (each processor)  --->
quadrature point (each processor), is my understanding correct ?
Maybe I can try output each ElementID within computeProperties() , the result could be correct ?


Thanks, if developers need any info., plz feel free let me know.
best regards,
tianwen

Hello

How to handle with the elemental communication between Material and UserObject ?

There are two directions here.
From material to UO:

materials precompute material properties, which UOs can just retrieve a reference to with getMaterialProperty

From UO to material:

materials can retrieve pointers to user objects of any type using the templated getUserObject<> so they can call any public API on those

For the AbaqusElementUO questions I dont know. @dschwen

hi, giud, I understood your kind answers. Thanks.
I think I did not explain my question very well.


these operations make sense to me, we can get the Material properties and the data calculated within UOs
via getMaterialProperty<>() and getUserObject<>(). The example BlockAverageValue in moose
explained it nicely.


I wanna dicuss Two situations, how to get expected output ? :


If I wanna output individually the ElementID of each element, could I just need to do this I/O operation within
computeProperties() ? but I confused that "the computeProperties() is work on element or (subdomains) processor ?"


although it's duplicated job, I wanna store one MaterialProperty[_qp] of each quadrature point within one shared
map container (std::map<dof_id_type, std::vector<Real>>   map[elementID][quadraturePoints]) via UO, and then, to get this
materialProperty of each quadrature point at Materials via
(Real thisMaterialProperty = UO.getMap(_current_element->id())[_qp]).




From the first case, the expected output should be Element Number is    x looped over each element and output this string number of elements times on terminal.
From the second case, the output of materialProperty from UO stored and the output of materialProperty by directly declareMaterialProperty in computeQpProperties() should be the same, but I tried before, it's not same. There is not any
communication between element by element and processor by processor, so I did not use threadJoin() and finalize().
If I got any misunderstanding, plz tell me ! Thanks

Updated...........
I tried directly output ElementID via computeProperties() or computeQpProperties() if and only if _tid=0 && _qp=0 condition.
The output of thread ID = 0 (maybe master) presented including 0th partial outputs of ElementID, two case are the same.
dose the terminal output have a constraint only for threadID 0 ? only threadID 0 processor will output on terminal.
how can I output ElementID of all elements ?
could I explain it if I did not do threadJoin( ) and finalize( ) within UO, the only threadID0 read the data of UO at materials ?

use --keep-cout on the command line to keep all the output.
I dont think we stop output from other threads, but we do stop output from other mpi processes.

f I wanna output individually the ElementID of each element, could I just need to do this I/O operation within
computeProperties() ? but I confused that "the computeProperties() is work on element or (subdomains) processor ?"

for what purpose? To look at it in a CSV?
Use an Element...VPP for that. They will output the id and locations

although it's duplicated job, I wanna store one MaterialProperty[_qp] of each quadrature point within one shared
map container (std::map<dof_id_type, std::vector>   map[elementID][quadraturePoints]) via UO, and then, to get this
materialProperty of each quadrature point at Materials via
(Real thisMaterialProperty = UO.getMap(_current_element->id())[_qp]).

using a map for material properties is unconventional and not really necessary. You'll need to be careful to execute the User Object early enough that the map is ready for wherever you plan to use it
Are you using threads? Or MPI? Or both?
For forming a map of all properties, I expect you may need to use threadJoin() for threads to perform a reduction of that map, though unless you want to distribute the map, I expect you do not need to use finalize()

use --keep-cout on the command line to keep all the output. I dont think we stop output from other threads, but we do stop output from other mpi processes.

hi giud, this make sense to me, Thanks.

f I wanna output individually the ElementID of each element, could I just need to do this I/O operation within
computeProperties() ? but I confused that "the computeProperties() is work on element or (subdomains) processor ?"

for what purpose? To look at it in a CSV? Use an Element...VPP for that. They will output the id and locations

although it's duplicated job, I wanna store one MaterialProperty[_qp] of each quadrature point within one shared
map container (std::map<dof_id_type, std::vector>   map[elementID][quadraturePoints]) via UO, and then, to get this
materialProperty of each quadrature point at Materials via
(Real thisMaterialProperty = UO.getMap(_current_element->id())[_qp]).

using a map for material properties is unconventional and not really necessary. You'll need to be careful to execute the User Object early enough that the map is ready for wherever you plan to use it
Are you using threads? Or MPI? Or both? For forming a map of all properties, I expect you may need to use threadJoin() for threads to perform a reduction of that map, though unless you want to distribute the map, I expect you do not need to use finalize()



(1) it's just simple test for my purpose, NVM. I will explain my purpose in below. sorry for this confusion.


(2) What I wanna do is, for instance, we consider HEX8 lagrangian element with 8 quadrature points


[1] calculate one scalar material property at quadrature point [_qp] in ComputeQpProperties(), such as hydrostatic stress. this done at time increment n.



[2] extra this hydrostatic stress material property < Real > and store them into a mapStored within UO by mapStored[elementIDs][quadrature points], as giud you said using getMaterialProperty<>
for instance, this material property at 0th quadrature point within 4th element, which stored in mapStored[4][0].


[3] do some elemental operations with 8 quadrature points from above stored mapStored, after that, we calculated a new material property < RealVectorValue > at each quadrature point. store these new material properties into mapNew [elementIDs][quadrature points], which contains < RealVectorValue >.



[4] we focus on time increment n+1 and go back to Material System. To obtain this mapNew in ComputeQpProperties() as giud you said using getUserObject<>. this new calculated < RealVectorValue > by UO will be used to calculate another MaterialProperty in current timestep, such as flux, and provide to computeQpResidual and computeQpJacobian.




This is what I ask the question about individual Elemental value, all UO operations just use quadrature points of same elements like tiny User-Element.
I already tried some followed above procedure, The result is strongly changed with different processors (MPI) used.
I did not use threads only MPI, is that means I do not need to use threadJoin( ) and finalize( ) ?
regards,
tianwen

To use threads you must implement threadJoin whenever a reduction operation is needed.
To use MPI / processes, similar for finalize()

The result is strongly changed with different processors (MPI) used

The element numbering is different in parallel. Use allow_renumbering = false in the Mesh block to keep the same ordering

[3] do some elemental operations with 8 quadrature points from above stored mapStored, after that, we calculated a new material property < RealVectorValue > at each quadrature point. store these new material properties into mapNew [elementIDs][quadrature points], which contains < RealVectorValue >.

I would recommend creating a second material property for the property retrieved by a UO then, this will simplify the logic.
I think you have the workflow well set up already?
Did you check that the user object is expected before the kernels/bcs/etc that need this custom material property?

Hi, giud, I re-view the Moose workshop slides and tried some different UOs-based.
for now, I got the correct results. the KeyPoint from my view, we should maintain the same data storage map over all processors, this is my previous misunderstanding. the replicated mesh as default.
Thanks for your all suggestions and help. I will mark as answer.
best regards,
tianwen

node.title: How external Fortran programs are programmed into mooseprojects
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello， everyone.
I am currently trying to get moose to compile one of my external Fortran programs, which has been modified to be compiled by gfortran as per your previous suggestion. However, I am currently experiencing some problems with the compilation process. How does compiling a Fortran program with moose generate the .mod file, when I see it compiling he reminds me of the missing  .mod file. So in order to compile successfully I have to copy the .mod compiled externally into it, which I think is a very stupid way, so I would like to ask you for help.
Here is the compilation script I wrote， SCAPN is  my external program.

yours
lvjiahui

@permcody @milljm
I think you can find examples of compiling fortran programs in moose in the solid_mechanics module
look at examples/examples/uel_build_tests
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/modules/solid_mechanics/examples/uel_build_tests

We need more details. Are you pulling in a few routines, or are you
planning on coupling in a complete project?
…
On Fri, Jun 28, 2024 at 9:38 AM Guillaume Giudicelli < ***@***.***> wrote:
 @permcody <https://github.com/permcody> @milljm
 <https://github.com/milljm>

 I think you can find examples of compiling fortran programs in moose in
 the solid_mechanics module
 look at examples/examples/uel_build_tests

 https://github.com/idaholab/moose/tree/next/modules/solid_mechanics/examples/uel_build_tests

 —

 .
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID:
 ***@***.***>

node.title: Two viscoelastic subdomains: material properties declared on block by multiple materials
node.bodyText:
After looking at some related tickets: 22281, etc., I still don't know how to proceed. I'm trying to run a file of uniaxial tension in a viscoelastic rectangle with a small region inside of it having different material parameters:
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  #density = 1e4
[]

[Mesh]
  [generated]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 40
    ny = 20
    xmax = 2
    ymax = 1
  []
  [block1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = generated
    block_id = 1
    bottom_left = '0.9 0.3 0'
    top_right = '1.1 0.7 0'
    location = OUTSIDE
  []
  [block2]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = block1
    block_id = 2
    bottom_left = '0.9 0.3 0'
    top_right = '1.1 0.7 0'
    location = INSIDE
  []
[]

[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]
  [all]
    strain = SMALL
    add_variables = true
    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yx stress_yy vonmises_stress'
  []
[]

[BCs]
  [left_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = left
    value = 0
  []
  [left_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = left
    value = 0
  []
  [right_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = right
    value = 0
  []
  [right_x]
    type = FunctionNeumannBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = right
    function = '600e6 * 0.2 * (1 + sin(2 * pi * t * 5))'
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [outer_mat]
    type = GeneralizedKelvinVoigtModel
    creep_modulus = 660e6
    creep_viscosity = 1
    young_modulus = 660e6
    poisson_ratio = 0.3
    block = 1
  []
  [inner_mat]
    type = GeneralizedKelvinVoigtModel
    creep_modulus = 100e4
    creep_viscosity = 2
    young_modulus = 100e4
    poisson_ratio = 0.3
    block = 2
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleInelasticStress
    inelastic_models = 'creep'
  []
  [creep]
    type = LinearViscoelasticStressUpdate
  []
  [strain]
    type = ComputeSmallStrain
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  []
[]

[UserObjects]
  [update_out]
    type = LinearViscoelasticityManager
    viscoelastic_model = 'outer_mat'
  []
  [update_inner]
    type = LinearViscoelasticityManager
    viscoelastic_model = 'inner_mat'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = NEWTON
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  end_time = 1
  dt = 0.01
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

But an error occurs:
 `*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the Problem 'MOOSE Problem' of type FEProblem.

The following material properties are declared on block 1 by multiple materials:
  Material Property             Material Objects
  mechanical_strain             all_strain strain 
  total_strain                  all_strain strain `

I tried to use base_names e.g. here but that only gave more errors. Any help appreciated.

Hello
The 'strain' material you defined overlaps with the 'strain' material that is created by the Physics
[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]
  [all]
    strain = SMALL
    add_variables = true
    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yx stress_yy vonmises_stress'
  []
[]

I dont think you need both. I think you could delete the material and select the strain model in the Physics block
Guillaume

Commenting out the strain material gives a separate error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the Problem 'MOOSE Problem' of type FEProblem.

Material property 'strain_increment', requested by 'stress' is not defined on block 1
Material property 'rotation_increment', requested by 'stress' is not defined on block 1
Material property 'strain_increment', requested by 'stress' is not defined on block 1
Material property 'strain_increment', requested by 'stress' is not defined on block 2
Material property 'rotation_increment', requested by 'stress' is not defined on block 2
Material property 'strain_increment', requested by 'stress' is not defined on block 2
```

Can you make the physics use an incremental strain model?
Those properties are only defined for incremental models

No the Physics module only allows small or finite as inputs:
*** ERROR *** Invalid option "INCREMENTAL" in MooseEnum.  Valid options (not case-sensitive) are "SMALL FINITE".
set incremental = true

I went back to using the normal mechanics kernel and the simpler LinearViscoelasticStress and a new error message is occuring:
*** ERROR *** Incompatible material and object blocks: /home/rmcavoy/projects/raptor/tendon/cgpt.i:102: (Materials/outer_mat/block) material defined on blocks 1,  block: object needs material on blocks 1, 2, 
Relevant input file:
`
[Mesh]
[generated]
type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
dim = 2
nx = 40
ny = 20
xmax = 2
ymax = 1
[]
[block1]
type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
input = generated
block_id = 1
bottom_left = '0.9 0.3 0'
top_right = '1.1 0.7 0'
location = OUTSIDE
[]
[block2]
type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
input = block1
block_id = 2
bottom_left = '0.9 0.3 0'
top_right = '1.1 0.7 0'
location = INSIDE
[]
[]
[Variables]
[./disp_x]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[../]
[./disp_y]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[../]
[]
[Kernels]
[SolidMechanics]
displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
use_displaced_mesh = true
[../]
[]
[BCs]
[left_x]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_x
boundary = left
value = 0
[]
[left_y]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_y
boundary = left
value = 0
[]
[right_y]
type = DirichletBC
variable = disp_y
boundary = right
value = 0
[]
[right_x]
type = FunctionNeumannBC
variable = disp_x
boundary = right
function = '600e6 * 0.2 * (1 + sin(2 * pi * t * 5))'
[]
[]
[Materials]
[outer_mat]
type = GeneralizedKelvinVoigtModel
creep_modulus = 660e6
creep_viscosity = 1
young_modulus = 660e6
poisson_ratio = 0.3
block = 1
[]
[inner_mat]
type = GeneralizedKelvinVoigtModel
creep_modulus = 100e4
creep_viscosity = 2
young_modulus = 100e4
poisson_ratio = 0.3
block = 2
[]
[stress]
type = ComputeLinearViscoelasticStress
[]
[strain]
type = ComputeSmallStrain
displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
[]
[]
[UserObjects]
[update_out]
type = LinearViscoelasticityManager
viscoelastic_model = 'outer_mat'
[]
[update_inner]
type = LinearViscoelasticityManager
viscoelastic_model = 'inner_mat'
[]
[]
[Executioner]
type = Transient
solve_type = NEWTON
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
petsc_options_value = 'lu'
end_time = 1
dt = 0.01
[]
[Outputs]
exodus = true
[]
`

set incremental = true

Still, nope:
*** ERROR *** Incompatible material and object blocks: /home/rmcavoy/projects/raptor/tendon/cgpt.i:85: (Materials/outer_mat/block) material defined on blocks 1,  block: object needs material on blocks 1, 2,

the property defined by 'outer_mat' is being request on two blocks '1,2' when it only defines it on block 1
maybe you are missing another material to define the same property as outer_mat?

set incremental = true

Still, nope:
*** ERROR *** Incompatible material and object blocks: /home/rmcavoy/projects/raptor/tendon/cgpt.i:85: (Materials/outer_mat/block) material defined on blocks 1, block: object needs material on blocks 1, 2, 

Is this from your new input or from the input with the Physics?
Input with Physics

node.title: how to impose the deformation output by abaqus to Moose
node.bodyText:
Hi
I build a cubic volume in Moose and want it to deform the way same as the simulation result obtained with ABAQUS, which means the displacements of each surface (or vertex) of the cubic be the same as ABAQUS.
I directly give the displacement to each surface like:
[BCs]
  [tdisp1]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0.003
  []
  [tdisp2]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0.0236
  []
  [tdisp3]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = bottom
    value = 0.0236
  []


  [tdisp4]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = top
    value = 0.0236
  []
  [tdisp5]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = top
    value = 0.0236
  []
  [tdisp6]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = top
    value = 0.0236
  []  
 
  [tdisp7]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = left
    value = 0.0302
  []
  [tdisp8]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = left
    value =  0.003
  []
  [tdisp9]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = left
    value =  -0.0112
  [] 

  [tdisp10]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = right
    value = 0.003
  []
  [tdisp11]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = right
    value = 0.003
  []
  [tdisp12]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = right
    value = 0.003
  [] 


  [tdisp13]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = back
    value = 0.0322
  []
  [tdisp14]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = back
    value = 0.0322
  []
  [tdisp15]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = back
    value = -0.0132
  [] 

  
  [tdisp16]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = front
    value = 0.0259
  []
  [tdisp17]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = front
    value = 0.0259
  []
  [tdisp18]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = front
    value =  0.0259
  [] 
[]

however, it always does not converge at iteration 0. The same situation when I prescibe the displacement to the 8 vertexes
Also, if the deformation gradient can be defined, it might also works, I found following discussion but still not understande how to do, may need some details.
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/discussions/19487

Hello
Can you set preset=false to all these boundary conditions and see if it converges?
Guillaume

thank you for your reply. No it doesn't work. I am applying a crystal plastic simulation of pure Ti in ABAQUS by using a UMAT without twinning mechanism, so I'm trying to export the deformation from ABAQUS result and give them to Moose. However, my boundary condition setting leads to divergence even I set preset=false. I think I will do my CP simulation of indentation totally within Moose. The discussions #16716, the input example (modules/contact/examples/3d_berkovich/indenter_berkovich_friction.i) and the vedios by Nicolò Grilli (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qG7EoX34hZ8) may help.

Also, after I read the modules/contact/examples/3d_berkovich/indenter_berkovich_friction.i, I cannot find the definition of crystal orientation nowhere, how can I give each grain an orientation (through bunger euler angle or orientation matrix) ? @GiudGiud

after a few searching, I found this :
/solid_mechanics/src/userobjects/EulerAngleFileReader.C

but what I'm interested in is the modified Kalidindi model for hcp :
[Materials]
    [elasticity_tensor]
       type = ComputeElasticityTensorCP
       C_ijkl = '1.622e5 9.18e4 6.88e4 1.622e5 6.88e4 1.805e5 4.67e4 4.67e4 4.67e4' 
    fill_method = symmetric9
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeMultipleCrystalPlasticityStress
    crystal_plasticity_models = 'twin_xtalpl'
    tan_mod_type = exact
  []
  [twin_xtalpl]
    type = CrystalPlasticityTwinningKalidindiUpdate
    base_name = twin
    crystal_lattice_type = HCP
    unit_cell_dimension = '2.934e-7 2.934e-7 4.657e-7' 
    number_slip_systems = 6
    slip_sys_file_name = 'hcp_tensile_twin_systems.txt'
    initial_twin_lattice_friction = 1140
    non_coplanar_coefficient_twin_hardening = 10000
    coplanar_coefficient_twin_hardening = 1000
    characteristic_twin_shear = 0.167
  []
[]

CrystalPlasticityTwinningKalidindiUpdate is under [Material] instead of [UserObjects], Can I apply the "EulerAngleFileReader" to define the orientation of crystal ?

Hello
The reader is a user object because that's all it does, read the angles from a file iirc.
Now the materials have to pull in the UserObject (using getUserObject on the problem) to query the angles.
If this has not been implemented for Kalindi, then you'll need to implement that

Use the parameters in ComputeElasticityTensorCP to provide the euler angles, options include:

euler_angle_1, euler_angle_2, and euler_angle_3
euler_angle_variables
read_prop_user_object, or
rotation_matrix
See the many example input files listed at the bottom of the documentation page for how to use one of these options: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/crystal_plasticity/ComputeElasticityTensorCP.html

If you are looking for a HCP specific constitutive model, I recommend the CrystalPlasticityHCPDislocationSlipBeyerleinUpdate. The twinning Kalidindi model with the HCP lattice is intended only for regression testing purposes
thank you @sapitts , I will try that !
